Name: Methanopyrus kandleri
Extended Metabolism: was not able to use any methanogenic substrates other than H2 and CO2.

Name: Geogemma barossii
Extended Metabolism:
Fe(III) was
reduced to Fe(II) with formation of the magnetic mineral magnetite. The use of Fe(III) as an electron acceptor was key to the isolation of strain 121, as
it does not use other known electron acceptors.

Name: Pyrolobus fumarii
Extended Metabolism: gaining energy by H2-oxidation. Nitrate, S2O3 2− , and low concentrations of O2 (up to 0.3% v/v) served as electron acceptors, yielding NH4 + , H2S, and H2O as end products, respectively. Growth was inhibited by acetate, pyruvate, glucose, starch, or sulfur

Name: Pyrococcus kukulkanii
Extended Metabolism: Grew on complex proteinaceous substrates such as yeast extract, peptone and tryptone, as well as on glycogen and starch. Elemental sulfur was required for growth and was reduced to hydrogen sulfide. The fermentation products from complex proteinaceous substrates were CO2 and H

Name: Pyrodictium brockii
Extended Metabolism: Hydrogen-sulphur-autotrophy

Name: Pyrodictium occultum
Extended Metabolism: Hydrogen-sulphur-autotrophy

Name: Methanopyrus kandleri
Extended Metabolism: H2/CO2 as energy and carbon sources

Name: Pyrococcus endeavori
Extended Metabolism: Reduces elemental sulphur but can grow very poorly in the absence of sulphur. Organic substrates utilized include yeast extract, peptone and amino acid hydrolysate as well as individual amino acids, the peptide Leu-Ser and starch.

Name: Pyrodictium abyssi
Extended Metabolism: Fermented carbohydrates, proteins, cell homogenates, acetate and formate. Isovalerate, isobutyrate, butanol and CO2 were detected as end products. Growth was stimulated by H2. In the presence of S°, H2S was formed.

Name: Hyperthermus butylicus
Extended Metabolism: utilizes peptide mixtures as carbon and energy sources, and forms H2S from elemental sulfur and molecular hydrogen as a growth-stimulating accessory energy source but not by sulfur respiration. The same fermentation products, C02, 1-butanol, acetic acid, phenylacetic acid, and a trace of hydroxyphenylacetic acid, are formed both with and without of So and H2.

Name: Pyrococcus yayanosii
Extended Metabolism: Growing on complex carbon sources such as peptone, tryptone, yeast extract or beef extract. Poor growth was recorded on casamino acids, and no growth on carbohydrates, alcohols or single amino acids. With appropriate carbon sources, growth was stimulated by elemental sulphur.

Name: Pyrococcus woesei
Extended Metabolism: Yeast extract and peptides (bactotryptone) and, barely polysaccharides, utilized by sulfur respiration, yeast extract also in the absence of sulfur and in the presence of H2, and polysaccharides efficiently in the presence of H1 and S°. No fermentation observed.

Name: Pyrobaculum aerophilum
Extended Metabolism: Growth inhibition by elemental sulfur. Heterotrophic growth on yeast extract, meat extract, tryptone, peptone, gelatin, casein, Casamino Acids, propionate, and acetate. Autotrophic growth by oxidation of hydrogen or thiosulfate. Oxygen, nitrate, and nitrite are possible electron acceptors.

Name: Pyrococcus glycovorans
Extended Metabolism: Grew preferentially in media containing complex proteinaceous carbon sources, glucose and elemental sulfur

Name: Pyrococcus furiosus
Extended Metabolism: growing on starch, maltose, peptone and complex organic substrates

Name: Thermococcus fumicolans
Extended Metabolism: Grows on proteolysis products and a mixture of amino acids. Sulfur is not necessary for growth but greatly enhances growth

Name: Pyrobaculum organotrophum
Extended Metabolism: The isolates grow facultatively chemolithoautotrophically or obligately heterotrophically. Molecular hydrogen or complex organic substances are used as electron donors. During heterotrophic growth, elemental sulfur, thiosulfate, sulfite, L(--)cystine and oxidized glutathione may serve as electron acceptors depending on the individual strain. Elemental sulfur is strictly required as an electron acceptor for autotrophic growth

Name: Pyrobaculum islandicum
Extended Metabolism: During heterotrophic growth, elemental sulfur, thiosulfate, sulfite, L(--)cystine and oxidized glutathione may serve as electron acceptors depending on the individual strain. Elemental sulfur is strictly required as an electron acceptor for autotrophic growth

Name: Pyrococcus horikoshii
Extended Metabolism: utilizes complex proteinaceous media (peptone, tryptone, or yeast extract), or a 21-amino-acid mixture supplemented with vitamins, as growth substrates. Sulfur greatly enhances growth.

Name: Pyrococcus abyssi
Extended Metabolism: fermenting peptides, or mixtures of amino acids to acetate, isovalerate, isobutyrate, propionate, H2 and CO2. Hydrogen inhibits growth unless sulfur is present. In the presence of sulfur, H2S is then produced

Name: Stetteria hydrogenophila
Extended Metabolism: Growth of the isolate was strictly dependent upon the presence of elemental sulfur in the culture medium and of hydrogen in the gas phase of the culutre, Large amounts of H2S were formed during growth. When H2/CO2 (80:20) atmosphere was replaced by 100% hydrogen atmosphere, growth was still possible, but the doubling time of the strain 4ABC was increased by a factor of six. They growth heterotrophically on yeast extract, peptone, trytone, casamino acids, or cell-free extracts of Pyrococcus furiosus or Thermococcus celer, but only in the presence of both molecular hydrogen and elemental sulfur. Hydrogen was obligately required as an electron donor. H2S is formed from sulfur during growth. Sulfur or Thiosulfate act as electron acceptors. The presence of CO2 stimulates growth.

Name: Thermoproteus uzoniensis
Extended Metabolism: organism grows anaerobically by fermenting peptides, concurrently reduction elemental sulfur to H2S. Fermentation products are acetate, isobutyrate, isovalerate.

Name: Pyrobaculum calidifontis
Extended Metabolism: Elemental sulfur inhibited cell growth under aerobic growth conditions, whereas thiosulfate stimulated cell growth. Under anaerobic growth conditions, nitrate served as a final electron acceptor, but nitrite or sulfur-containing compounds such as elemental sulfur, thiosulfate, sulfate and sulfite could not act as final electron acceptors.

Name: Pyrobaculum arsenaticum
Extended Metabolism: growth on a mixture of yeast extract, meat extract, peptone and brain heart infusion. Organotrophically, hydrogen inhibits growth. Hydrogen inhibition can be overcome by addition of arsenate, selenate, sulfur or thiosulfate. Formation of realgar in the presence of arsenate and thiosulfate or arsenate and L-cysteine (H2-CO2 gas phase). Formation of elemental selenium during organotrophic growth on selenate (H2-CO2 or N2-CO2 gas phase). Lithoautotrophic growth by reduction of arsenate, elemental sulfur or thiosulfate with hydrogen as electron donor. H2S is formed from elemental sulfur or thiosulfate, arsenite from arsenate

Name: Thermococcus peptonophilus
Extended Metabolism: Elemental sulfur stimulated the growth rate fourfold. Ammonium slightly stimulated growth. Both tryptone and yeast extract allowed growth as sole carbon sources; these isolates were not able to utilize or grow exclusively on sucrose, glucose, maltose, succinate, pyruvate, propionate, acetate, or free amino acids.

Name: Thermococcus eurythermalis
Extended Metabolism: utilize yeast extract, peptone, tryptone and starch as the single carbon source for growth. Elemental sulfur and cysteine stimulated growth; however, these molecules were not necessary

Name: Thermococcus hydrothermalis
Extended Metabolism: grows preferentially on proteolysis products, on a mixture of 20 amino acids, and on maltose in the presence of elemental sulfur

Name: Thermococcus kodakarensis
Extended Metabolism: Elemental sulfur, as a terminal electron acceptor, is required for heterotrophic growth on yeast extract, tryptone, peptone and free amino acids (producing hydrogen sulfide). Grows without elemental sulfur through fermentation with the addition of starch, maltooligosaccharides, cyclodextrins or pyruvate (producing molecular hydrogen).

Name: Pyrobaculum neutrophilum
Extended Metabolism: utilized complex proteinaceous compounds as electron donors and ferrihydrite, Fe(III) citrate, nitrate, thiosulfate, selenite, selenate and arsenate as electron acceptors for growth

Name: Ignisphaera aggregans
Extended Metabolism: Ferments both poly- and disaccharides

Name: Pyrobaculum ferrireducens
Extended Metabolism: metabolized complex proteinaceous compounds as electron donors and ferrihydrite, Fe(III) citrate, nitrate, thiosulfate, selenite, selenate and arsenate as electron acceptors for growth

Name: Staphylothermus marinus
Extended Metabolism: Strictly anaerobic and So -dependent. Heterotrophic growth on complex organic substrates and elemental sulfur with the concomitant formation of CO2, acetate, isovalerate and H2S.

Name: Ignicoccus hospitalis
Extended Metabolism: growth in the presence of H2 and CO2 with sulfur as electron acceptor. No chemo-organotrophic growth on meat extract, yeast extract, peptone, Casamino acids, gelatin, starch, formate, acetate or glucose. Sulfate, sulfite, sulfide, thiosulfate, tetrathionate, nitrate and oxygen are not used as electron acceptors. H2S is formed during growth.

Name: Ignicoccus islandicus
Extended Metabolism: They gained energy by reduction of elemental sulfur using molecular hydrogen as the electron donor.

Name: Ignicoccus pacificus
Extended Metabolism: They gained energy by reduction of elemental sulfur using molecular hydrogen as the electron donor.

Name: Vulcanisaeta moutnovskia
Extended Metabolism: Metabolic pathway analysis revealed that utilization of polysaccharides and proteins involve the function of numerous encoded hydrolytic enzymes.

Name: Nanoarchaeum equitans
Extended Metabolism: lack means to metabolize compounds on its own

Name: Pyrobaculum oguniense
Extended Metabolism: 60 min under anaerobic and microaerobic conditions. Heterotrophic growth with yeast extract and trypticase peptone. Sulfur inhibits aerobic growth but stimulates anaerobic growth. Oxygen, thiosulfate, sulfur, -cystine and glutathione (oxidized form) are possible electron acceptors.

Name: Desulfurococcus amylolyticus
Extended Metabolism: fermented a wide range of substrates including proteins: α-keratin, albumin and gelatin. Elemental sulfur was not essential for growth, but stimulated growth.

Name: Hyperthermus hephaesti
Extended Metabolism: Strain Ro04 grew on peptides, reduced poorly crystalline iron oxide to black ferromagnetic magnetite and produced acetate and minor amounts of ethanol. It did not grow on any other terminal electron acceptor or purely by fermentation.

Name: Pyrodictium delaneyi
Extended Metabolism: hydrogenotrophic and reduced Fe(III) oxide to magnetite and NO3

Name: Aeropyrum camini
Extended Metabolism: strictly aerobic heterotroph capable of growing on complex proteinaceous substrates such as yeast extract and tryptone

Name: Desulfurococcus mobilis
Extended Metabolism: utilizes peptides as carbon and energy sources and reduces elemental sulfur to H2S

Name: Desulfurococcus saccharovorans
Extended Metabolism: utilizes peptides as carbon and energy sources and reduces elemental sulfur to H2S

Name: Thermoproteus neutrophilus
Extended Metabolism: T. neutrophilus appears to use elemental sulfur as its sole electron acceptor.

Name: Acidianus infernus
Extended Metabolism: Growth is obligately chemolithotrophic and So dependent by oxidation or reduction of So

Name: Thermoproteus tenax
Extended Metabolism: Produce H2S from elemental sulfur and hydrogen derived from organic substrates including glucose, starch, glycogen, ethanol, methanol, formate, formamide, malate, fumarate but not lactate, acetate and pyruvate. Malate replaces sulfur as electron acceptor. Stimulated by less than 0.5 gil yeast extract. Form CO 2,

Name: Pyrobaculum igneiluti
Extended Metabolism: Strictly anaerobic and uses TYB, casamino acids, peptone and gelatin as energy sources. Autotrophic growth in H2/CO2 is also observed. Unable to oxidize cellobiose, galactose, sucrose, acetate, trehalose, sorbitol, maltose hydrate, glucose, mannitol, sucrose, pyruvate, lactose or lactate. For terminal electron acceptors, only able to reduce thiosulfate and Fe(III) (ferrihydrite). Unable to reduce sulfate, sulfite, elemental sulfur, nitrate, L-cystine or oxidized glutathione.

Name: Thermococcus gammatolerans
Extended Metabolism: utilized yeast extract, tryptone and peptone. Elemental sulfur or cystine was required for growth and reduced to hydrogen sulfide

Name: Thermococcus litoralis
Extended Metabolism: They grow obligately heterotrophically on yeast extract, peptone, meat extract, casein and tryptone and are able to reduce sulfur. Slight growth on pyruvate.

Name: Thermococcus marinus
Extended Metabolism: These strains were obligate anaerobic heterotrophs that utilized yeast extract, tryptone, and peptone as a carbon source for growth. Ten amino acids were essential for the growth of strain EJ1T, such as arginine, aspartic acid, isoleucine, leucine, methionine, phenylalanine, proline, threonine, tyrosine, and valine, while strain EJ2T was unable to grow on a mixture of amino acids. Elemental sulfur or cystine was required for EJ2T growth and was reduced to hydrogen sulfide. Rifampicin inhibited growth for both strains EJ1T and EJ2T. The G+C contents of the genomic DNA were 52.3 and 54.5 mol% for EJ1T and EJ2T, respectively

Name: Thermococcus radiotolerans
Extended Metabolism: These strains were obligate anaerobic heterotrophs that utilized yeast extract, tryptone, and peptone as a carbon source for growth. Ten amino acids were essential for the growth of strain EJ1T, such as arginine, aspartic acid, isoleucine, leucine, methionine, phenylalanine, proline, threonine, tyrosine, and valine, while strain EJ2T was unable to grow on a mixture of amino acids. Elemental sulfur or cystine was required for EJ2T growth and was reduced to hydrogen sulfide. Rifampicin inhibited growth for both strains EJ1T and EJ2T. The G+C contents of the genomic DNA were 52.3 and 54.5 mol% for EJ1T and EJ2T, respectively

Name: Thermococcus nautili
Extended Metabolism: It grew preferentially in the presence of elemental sulfur or cystine, which are reduced to H2S, on complex organic substrates such as yeast extract, tryptone, peptone, Casamino acids and casein. Slow growth was observed on starch and pyruvate.

Name: Thermofilum pendens
Extended Metabolism: The fraction alone was unable to support growth which required yeast extract or tryptone or gelatin. Sucrose (0.2 gil) caused a further stimulation but by itself could not replace the other carbon sources. Sulfur and H2S were required. Growth was accompanied by the consumption of sulfur and the formation of CO2 and H2S indicating that this organism, like Desulfurococcus, exists by sulfur respiration of peptides.

Name: Aquifex pyrophilus
Extended Metabolism: Molecular hydrogen, thiosulfate and elemental sulfur serve as electron donors and oxygen and nitrate as electron acceptors. Sulfuric acid formed from So and thiosulfate. H2S produced from So and H2•

Name: Aquifex aeolicus
Extended Metabolism: It feeds on molecular hydrogen, carbon dioxide, molecular oxygen, and mineral nutrients, releasing only water. Instead of H2, inorganic sulphur compounds can also be oxidized, up to sulphate

Name: Sulfolobus tengchongensis
Extended Metabolism: Strain RT8-4 is capable of utilizing tryptone, D-xylose, D-arabinose, D-galactose, maltose, sucrose, D-fructose, or L-glutamic acid as the sole source of carbon. D-Glucose and D-mannose are not utilized.

Name: Thermococcus barophilus
Extended Metabolism: utilized yeast extract, beef extract and peptone for growth. Growth was optimal in the presence of elemental sulfur. Rifampicin and chloramphenicol inhibited growth

Name: Thermogladius calderae
Extended Metabolism: Strain 1633T grew on yeast extract, beef extract, peptone, cellulose and cellobiose. No growth was detected on other sugars or carbohydrates, organic acids, or under autotrophic conditions. The only detected growth products were CO2, acetate, and H2. The growth rate was stimulated by elemental sulfur, which was reduced to hydrogen sulfide

Name: Thermococcus gorgonarius
Extended Metabolism: obligate anaerobes, fermenting peptides in the case of strain W-12. Elemental sulfur is required for growth and is reduced to hydrogen sulfide.

Name: Thermococcus pacificus
Extended Metabolism: obligate anaerobes, fermenting peptides and starch in the case of P-4. Elemental sulfur is required for growth and is reduced to hydrogen sulfide.

Name: Thermococcus henrietii
Extended Metabolism: grew chemoorganoheterotrophically on complex proteinaceous substrates. Its growth was highly stimulated by the presence of elemental sulphur or l-cystine, which were reduced to hydrogen sulfide

Name: Thermococcus sp
Extended Metabolism: Grew under CO in gas phase. Strain AM4 did not grow in medium 1 with 0.05, or 0.1, or 1.0 g l)1 of yeast extract without CO in the gas phase under N2 atmosphere. Strain AM4 was able to grow in the same medium supplemented with 10 g l)1 of S0 under N2 atmosphere with 1 g l)1 of yeast extract or soybean extract or peptone.

Name: Sulfolobus yangmingensis
Extended Metabolism: utilizes sugars and amino acids effectively as sole carbon sources, that grows on elemental sulfur and reduced sulfur compounds.

Name: Thermococcus prieurii
Extended Metabolism: The novel isolate grew by fermentation or sulphur respiration on a variety of organic compounds. It was a chemoorganoheterotrophic archaeon growing preferentially with yeast extract, peptone and tryptone as carbon and energy sources and sulphur and organic compounds as electron acceptors; it also grew on maltose and starch. Sulphur or l-cystine were required for growth and were reduced to hydrogen sulfide.

Name: Thermofilum adornatus
Extended Metabolism: It grows chemoorganoheterotrophically on peptone, yeast extract, AMC, microcrystalline cellulose (Avicel), β-glucan, starch, cellobiose, glucose, lactose, mannose and pyruvate. It does not utilize tryptone, casein, α-cellulose, CMC, lichenan, gelatin, chitin, chitosan, xylan, keratin, mannan, glucomannan, glycerol, sucrose, maltose, xylose, and arabinose.

Name: Thermococcus aggregans
Extended Metabolism: a mixed organic acid fermentation from proteinaceous substrates; however, acetate was the sole organic acid produced from carbohydrate fermentation

Name: Thermococcus cleftensis
Extended Metabolism: S is not essential for growth, but significantly stimulates growth. Hydrogen (.2 mM) is produced in the absence of sulfur. Heterotrophic growth occurs on complex proteinaceous substrates (yeast extract, tryptone and casein), maltose, cellobiose and a mixture of 20 amino acids when vitamins are present. Yeast extract (0.01 %, w/v) and vitamins are required for growth.

Name: Thermococcus thioreducens
Extended Metabolism: Obligately dependent upon elemental sulfur. Catalase-negative. Grows with peptone, bacto-tryptone, Casamino acids and yeast extract as electron donors, but no growth on d-glucose, fructose, maltose, sucrose, d-mannitol, glycerol, methanol, ethanol, butyrate, propionate, acetate, formate, lactate, pyruvate, citrate or amino acids. Thiosulfate, sulfite, sulfate, Fe(III) and nitrate cannot support growth as electron acceptors.

Name: Pyrobaculum yellowstonensis sp
Extended Metabolism: Strain WP30 requires components in yeast extract (or amino acids) as a carbon and energy source and elemental sulfur and/or arsenate as an electron acceptor. chemoorganoheterotroph and requires elemental sulfur and/or arsenate as an electron acceptor. Growth in the presence of elemental sulfur and arsenate resulted in the formation of thioarsenates and polysulfides

Name: Thermococcus stetteri
Extended Metabolism: No growth without elemental sulfur. The energy substrates utilized are peptone, casein hydrolysate, trypticase, starch, and pectin. Produces H2S, CO2, acetate, isobutyrate and isovalerate. No growth on free amino acids, glucose, maltose, sucrose, cellulose, ethanol, methanol, acetate, propionate, and H2/C02•

Name: Thermococcus celer
Extended Metabolism: utilizes peptides and protein, which are oxidized to CO(2) by sulfur respiration

Name: Saccharolobus caldissimus
Extended Metabolism: Heterotrophic growth occurs on following complex substrates (yeast extract, peptone, tryptone, casamino acids) and sugars (starch, sucrose, lactose, maltose, raffinose, D-glucose, D-galactose, D-mannose, D-arabinose and L-arabinose). Chemolithotrophic growth occurs on pyrite (FeS2 ) but not on elemental sulfur, K2S4O6 , and oxidation of hydrogen

Name: Pyrococcus chitonophagus
Extended Metabolism: using chitin, yeast extract, meat extract, and peptone for growth. Chitin was fermented to H2, CO 2, NH 3, acetate, and formate. H2S was formed in the presence of sulfur

Name: Thermococcus acidaminovorans
Extended Metabolism: grows heterotrophically on defined amino acids and complex organic substrates such as casamino acids, yeast extract, peptone, meat extract, tryptone, and casein. Polysulfide and elemental sulfur are reduced to H2S. In the absence of polysulfide or elemental sulfur, the isolate grows at a significantly reduced rate. Growth is not influenced by the presence of H2.

Name: Thermococcus siculi
Extended Metabolism: Utilizes yeast extract, tryptone, peptone, and casein. Sulfur is not required for growth but significantly stimulates growth. Cystine supports rapid growth and is able to substitute elemental sulfur.

Name: Thermogladius shockii
Extended Metabolism: Species is capable of fermenting yeast, peptone, tryptone, beef extract, and casein

Name: Methanocaldococcus sp
Note: This strain is notable for fixing nitrogen at the highest known temperature of nitrogen fixers recorded to date

Name: Acidilobus aceticus
Extended Metabolism: It fermented starch, forming acetate as the main growth product. Other growth substrates were yeast extract, beef extract and soya extract. Growth on yeast extract, beef extract and soya extract was stimulated by elemental sulfur, which was reduced to H2S. Acetate, arabinose, cellulose, formate, fructose, galactose, glucose, glycine, guar gum, lichenan, malate, maltose, methanol, pectin, pyruvate, propionate, xylan, xylose or a mixture of amino acids failed to support growth both in the presence and the absence of sulfur. When starch was used as the growth substrate, yeast extract (100 mg/l) was required as a growth factor.

Name: Thermosulfurimonas dismutans
Extended Metabolism: Grows with elemental sulfur as an energy source and bicarbonate/CO2 as a carbon source. Elemental sulfur is disproportionated to sulfide and sulfate. Growth is enhanced with poorly crystalline iron(III) oxide (ferrihydrite) as a sulfide-scavenging agent. Able to grow by disproportionation of thiosulfate and sulfite. In the presence of elemental sulfur and ferrihydrite, malate and maleinate stimulate growth. In the presence of thiosulfate, molecular hydrogen stimulates growth. Formate, methanol, ethanol, n-propanol, i-propanol, butanol, acetate, propionate, butyrate, lactate, pyruvate, fumarate, succinate, tartrate, oxalate, citrate, glycerol, glycine, alanine, peptone, yeast extract and H2/CO2 do not stimulate growth in the presence of elemental sulfur and ferrihydrite. Does not ferment glucose, fructose, maltose, sucrose, cellobiose, arabinose or malate. Does not reduce sulfate, nitrate, poorly crystalline iron(III) oxide, iron(III) citrate, 9,10-anthraquinone 2,6-disulfonate, fumarate and oxygen with acetate, lactate, ethanol, pyruvate, malate, peptone and H2 as electron donors.

Name: Geoglobus ahangari
Extended Metabolism:
The isolate was capable of growth with H2 as the sole electron donor coupled to the reduction of Fe(III), This isolate is the first example of a hyperthermophile capable of
oxidation long-chain fatty acids anaerobically without the need for an organic carbon source. This is the first example of a dissimilatory Fe(III)-reduction micro-organism capable of growing autotrophically on hydrogen. I

Name: Methanotorris igneus
Extended Metabolism: capable of using hydrogen and carbon dioxide as sole energy and carbon sources. Formate was utilized as an alternative energy source

Name: Methanocaldococcus infernus
Extended Metabolism: The organism uses H2 and CO2 as the only substrate for growth and methane production. Tungsten, selenium and yeast extract stimulate growth significantly. In the presence of CO2 and H2, the organism reduces elemental sulphur to hydrogen sulphide.

Name: Methanocaldococcus jannaschii
Extended Metabolism: using H2 and CO2. No growth is observed when yeast extract, acetate, methanol or formate is used as the electron donor and carbon source, nor do they stimulate growth in the presence of H2 and CO2. No growth is observed when nitrate (10 mM KNO3) or nitrogen gas (N2) are given as sole nitrogen sources.

Name: Thermococcus paralvinellae
Extended Metabolism: S is not essential for growth, but stimulates growth and results in a higher growth yield. Hydrogen (.2 mM) is produced in the absence of sulfur. Heterotrophic growth occurs on complex proteinaceous substrates (yeast extract, tryptone and casein), maltose, cellobiose and a mixture of 20 amino acids when vitamins are present. No growth is observed by nitrate or sulfate reduction.

Name: Thermococcus aegaeicus
Extended Metabolism: utilizing complex organic compounds like yeast extract, peptone and tryptone as carbon source. Starch can be utilized under an N# }CO# atmosphere but not under an H# }CO# atmosphere. No growth on pyruvate, malt extract, maltose and casein. Elemental sulfur stimulates growth.

Name: Thermococcus guaymasensis
Extended Metabolism: a mixed organic acid fermentation from proteinaceous substrates; however, acetate was the sole organic acid produced from carbohydrate fermentation

Name: Vulcanisaeta distributa
Extended Metabolism: All of the isolates utilized maltose, starch, malate, yeast extract, peptone, beef extract, Casamino acids and gelatin as carbon sources. All of the isolates tested utilized sulfur and thiosulfate as electron acceptors. None of the isolates tested utilized fumarate, malate or nitrate as electron acceptors.

Name: Thermococcus coalescens
Extended Metabolism: Sulfur is not necessary for growth but significantly enhances growth, that grew on either yeast extract or tryptone as the sole growth substrate.

Name: Archaeoglobus profundus
Extended Metabolism: sulfate reduction, Sulfate, thiosulfate and sulfite served as electron acceptors. Elemental sulfur inhibited growth. In contrast to A. fulgidus, the new isolates were obligate mixotrophs strictly requiring H2 and an organic carbon source (e. g. acetate)

Name: Ferroglobus placidus
Extended Metabolism: It was isolated based on its ability to use ferrous iron as an electron donor, and was also shown to use hydrogen and sulfide as electron donors, with nitrate or thiosulfate as electron acceptors [1]. Subsequently, it was shown to produce N2O from nitrite, which is an unusual ability for an anaerobic organism [2]. It can also oxidize acetate and several aromatic compounds using ferric iron as the electron acceptor [3,4]. F. placidus is the first archaeon found to anaerobically oxidize aromatic compounds

Name: Staphylothermus hellenicus
Extended Metabolism: Grows with yeast extract as carbon source, but growth on peptone as carbon source is poor. Growth is absolutely dependent on elemental sulfur

Name: Thermosphaera aggregans
Extended Metabolism: Heterotrophic growth with yeast extract. Peptone stimulates growth. CO,, H,, acetate and isovalerate formed as metabolic products. Growth inhibition by sulfur or hydrogen.

Name: Thermococcus alcaliphilus
Extended Metabolism: The isolate fermented yeast extract, peptone, meat extract, tryptone, and casein. Isovalerate, isobutyrate, propionate, acetate, CO2, NH3, and H2S (in the presence of S degrees ) were detected as end products.

Name: Thermococcus atlanticus
Extended Metabolism: grows preferentially in the presence of elemental sulfur, polysulfur, cystine, or L-cysteine. The microorganism requires rich proteinaceous substrates. BHI-S medium supports rapid growth, with a final concentration of more than 1.2·109 cells ml–1, but strain MA898 exhibits poor growth on 2216S medium (yeast/ peptone) and poor growth on starch

Name: Thermococcus waiotapuensis
Extended Metabolism: The strain grows heterotrophically on complex proteinaceous substrates or on appropriate salts plus amino acid mixtures and is also able to utilize maltose, starch, and pyruvate. Elemental sulfur could be replaced by cystine or thioglycollate.

Name: Thermofilum uzonense
Extended Metabolism: organothrophically using polysaccharides (starch and glucomannan), yeast extract or peptone as substrates.

Name: Caldivirga maquilingensis
Extended Metabolism: utilized glycogen, gelatin, beef extract, peptone, tryptone and yeast extract as carbon sources. They required sulfur, thiosulfate or sulfate as electron acceptors

Name: Thermoproteus thermophilus
Extended Metabolism: Strain CBA1502T utilized d-arabinose, beef extract, Casamino acids, formate, fumarate, peptone, pyruvate, trimethylamine and yeast extract as energy substrates, and d-arabinose, formate, pyruvate and yeast extract as carbon sources. Fumarate, sulfate, sulfur and thiosulfate functioned as electron acceptors, but not ferric chloride, nitrate, malate or oxidized glutathione.

Name: Vulcanisaeta thermophila
Extended Metabolism: Fumarate, malate, oxidized glutathione, sulfur and thiosulfate are utilized as electron acceptors; whereas FeCl3, nitrate, and sulfate are not. Beef extract, Casamino acids, fumarate, d-galactose, gelatin, lactose, d-maltose and yeast extract are utilized as carbon sources; whereas acetate, d-arabinose, butyrate, citrate, formate, d-fructose, d-glucose, l-malate, d-mannose, methanol, methylamine, peptone, pyruvate, starch, succinate, sucrose, trimethylamine and d-xylose are not. Cells tolerate a low level of oxygen [5.0 % (v/v) air in N2] with sodium thiosulfate as an electron acceptor.

Name: Sulfolobus solfataricus
Extended Metabolism: limited in the utilization of simple carbon sources.  Sulfolobus strains can use single amino acids much more readily as the sole nitrogen source than as the sole carbon source.

Name: Thermodesulfobacterium geofontis
Extended Metabolism: Molecular hydrogen or formate serve as electron donors and CO2 is required as the carbon source. Sulfate, thiosulfate, and elemental sulfur are reduced to sulfide when provided as dissimilatory electron acceptors. Growth is not observed on lactate, acetate, pyruvate, benzoate, oleic acid, or ethanol in the presence of sulfate. Traces of yeast extract are required for growth.

Name: Acidilobus saccharovorans
Extended Metabolism: fermented a wide range of carbohydrates, including polysaccharides. Acetate, ethanol and lactate were the fermentation products. Growth was stimulated by elemental sulfur and thiosulfate, which were reduced to hydrogen sulfide.

Name: Methanocaldococcus bathoardescens
Extended Metabolism: autotrophic growth occurs via methanogenesis using H2 and CO2. No growth is observed when yeast extract, acetate, methanol or formate is used as the electron donor and carbon source, nor do they stimulate growth in the presence of H2 and CO2

Name: Sulfolobus solfataricus
Extended Metabolism: limited in the utilization of simple carbon sources.  Sulfolobus strains can use single amino acids much more readily as the sole nitrogen source than as the sole carbon source.

Name: Methanocaldococcus villosus
Extended Metabolism: The cells gained their energy exclusively by reduction of CO(2) with H(2). Selenate, tungstate and yeast extract stimulated growth significantly.

Name: Sulfolobus solfataricus
Extended Metabolism: Utilized simple and complex carbohydrates as carbon sources as well as most amino acids except alanine and asparagine.  Sulfolobus strains can use single amino acids much more readily as the sole nitrogen source than as the sole carbon source.

Name: Acidianus manzaensis
Extended Metabolism: autotrophically using H2 or S0 as an electron donor and Fe3+ as an electron acceptor, and also could grow heterotrophically using some organic compounds. Fe3+ and O2 served as electron acceptors for growth

Name: Palaeococcus pacificus
Extended Metabolism: capable of utilizing complex organic compounds and organic acids including yeast extract, peptone, tryptone, casein, starch, Casamino acids, citrate, lactate, acetate, fumarate, propanoate and pyruvate for growth. It was strictly anaerobic and facultatively dependent on elemental sulfur or sulfate as electron acceptors, but did not reduce sulfite, thiosulfate, Fe(III) or nitrate. The presence of elemental sulfur enhanced growth.

Name: Thermococcus onnurineus
Extended Metabolism: utilized yeast extract, beef extract, tryptone, peptone, casein, and starch as carbon and energy sources. Elemental sulfur was required for growth and was reduced to hydrogen sulfide.

Name: Thermococcus profundus
Extended Metabolism: Requires elemental sulfur. Organic substrates utilized included tryptone, peptone, casein, gelatin and yeast extract. Growth of this organism was observed on a synthetic medium containing pyruvate, maltose or starch

Name: Thermotoga maritima
Extended Metabolism: They were able to utilize glucose, ribose, xylose, galactose, sucrose, maltose, starch, glycogen, yeast extract, and whole cell extracts of eubacteria (e.g. of Lactobacillus bavaricus) and archaebacteria (e.g. of Methanococcus thermolithotrophicus, Methanobacterium thermoautotrophicum, Pyrodictium brockii).

Name: Thermotoga neapolitana
Extended Metabolism: able to use ribose, xylose, glucose, sucrose, maltose, lactose, galactose, starch, and glycogen as substrates. No growth occurred on acetate, lactate, formate, pyruvate, propionate, ethanol, methanol, glycerol, glutamate, glycine, and casamino acids.

Name: Caldicellulosiruptor bescii
Extended Metabolism: Utilizes arabinose, CMC, cellobiose, crystalline cellulose (Avicel and sigmacell-20), b-cyclodextrin, filter paper (Whatman), fructose, galactose, glucose, glycogen, lactose, maltose, mannose, melibiose, pectin, pullulan, rhamnose, starch, sucrose, trehalose, xylan (beechwood, birchwood and oat spelts) and xylose

Name: Thermococcus camini
Extended Metabolism: Grew on complex organic substrates, such as yeast extract, tryptone, peptone or beef extract, preferentially in the presence of elemental sulphur or l-cystine; however, these molecules were not necessary for growth

Name: Fervidobacterium changbaicum
Extended Metabolism: Can utilize glucose, lactose, d-fructose, sucrose, maltose, starch, sorbitol, cellobiose, trehalose dihydrate, d-galactose, meso-erythritol, dulcitol, chrysanthanol, melibiose, pyruvate, dextrin and glycerin, but not d-raffinose, d-glucuronic acid, agarose, l-rhamnose, d-gluconic acid lactone, sodium malate, mannose, mannitol, l-arabinose or ribose. Sulphur powder can stimulate growth

Name: Thermococcus piezophilus
Extended Metabolism: stimulation of growth by sulphur containing compounds

Name: Pseudothermotoga hypogea
Extended Metabolism: Uses D-glucose, DL-fructose, D-galactose, DL-lactose, DL-maltose, D-mannose, D-sucrose, D-Ylose, and xylan but not D-arabinose, D-ribose, L-sorbose, Lxylose, acetate, butyrate, lactate, or propionate. Ferments yeast extract and bio-Trypticase. Requires yeast extract or bio-Trypticase for growth on carbohydrates. Yeast extract cannot be replaced by Casamino Acids, a vitamin solution, or a mixture of Casamino Acids and vitamins. The end products of glucose and xylose fermentation are acetate, CO,, H,, L-alanine, and traces of ethanol. Uses thiosulfate as an electron acceptor during glucose fermentation, and under these conditions the biomass is greater than the biomass obtained with no added electron acceptor. H,S is produced from thiosulfate-reduction. Elemental sulfur cannot be used as an electron acceptor, and growth is not inhibited by elemental sulfur.

Name: Vulcanisaeta souniana
Extended Metabolism: All of the isolates utilized maltose, starch, malate, yeast extract, peptone, beef extract, Casamino acids and gelatin as carbon sources. All of the isolates tested utilized sulfur and thiosulfate as electron acceptors. None of the isolates tested utilized fumarate, malate or nitrate as electron acceptors.

Name: Acidilobus sulfurireducens
Extended Metabolism: Growth on peptone, yeast extract, glycogen, gelatin, and pine needle extract as carbon and energy source coupled to obligate S0 respiration. Ammonia is produced and excreted into culture medium

Name: Caldisphaera draconis
Extended Metabolism: Growth on peptone, yeast extract, glycogen, gelatin, and pine needle extract as carbon and energy source coupled to obligate S0 respiration. Ammonia is produced and excreted into culture medium.

Name: Desulfurococcus fermentans
Extended Metabolism: hydrolysis and/or fermentation of a wide range of polymeric and monomeric substrates, including agarose, amygdalin, arabinose, arbutin, casein hydrolysate, cellulose (filter paper, microcrystalline cellulose, carboxymethyl cellulose), dextran, dulcitol, fructose, lactose, laminarin, lichenan, maltose, pectin, peptone, ribose, starch and sucrose.

Name: Thermocrinis ruber
Extended Metabolism: Molecular hydrogen, thiosulfate, elemental sulfur, formate, and formamide serve as electron donors, and oxygen serves as an electron acceptor. CO2, formate, and formamide are used as carbon sources. Ammonia is formed from formamide. meso-Diaminopimelic acid is present. Catalase positive

Name: Archaeoglobus lithotrophicus
Extended Metabolism: reductive acetyl-CoA pathway is the only functioning CO2 fixation pathway in ‘A. lithotrophicus’.

Name: Methanocaldococcus vulcanius
Extended Metabolism: The new isolate used H2 and CO2 as the only substrates for growth and methane production. Tungsten, selenium and yeast extract stimulated growth significantly. In the presence of C02 and H2 the organism reduced elemental sulphur to hydrogen sulphide

Name: Thermocrinis albus
Extended Metabolism: Isolate HI 11/12 grew optimally under microaerophilic conditions when hydrogen and sulfur were provided simultaneously as electron donors. isolate HI 11/12 were unable to metabolize formaldehyde (0.001%–0.1%, wt/vol), formate (0.1%, wt/vol), or formamide (0.1%, wt/vol) either microaerophilically with oxygen or anaerobically with nitrate as the electron acceptor.

Name: Palaeococcus ferrophilus
Extended Metabolism: capable of utilizing proteinaceous substrates such as yeast extract, peptone, tryptone and casein in the presence of elemental sulfur or ferrous iron

Name: Archaeoglobus fulgidus
Extended Metabolism: Sulfate e- acceptor

Name: Thermotoga petrophila
Extended Metabolism: Requires yeast extract, peptone, glucose, galactose, fructose, ribose, arabinose, sucrose, lactose, maltose, starch or cellulose as the sole carbon and energy source. The end products from glucose fermentation are acetate, lactate, H2 and CO2. While the cells reduce elemental sulfur or thiosulfate to H2S, their growth rate and cellular yield decrease in the presence of these electron acceptors

Name: Fervidobacterium thailandense
Extended Metabolism: ferments proteins and several carbohydrates including glucose, maltose, sucrose, fructose, cellobiose, CM-cellulose and starch. However, does not ferment lactose, galactose, trehalose, arabinose, mannose, xylose, sorbitol, mannitol or cellulose. Elemental sulfur stimulates growth. Thiosulfate and nitrate do not influence growth.

Name: Thermococcus sibiricus
Extended Metabolism: Organotroph, fermenting peptides. No growth was found on sugars, polysaccharides, organic acids, alcohols, or molecular hydrogen. Elemental sulfur stimulates fermentative growth on peptides in closed vessels.

Name: Thermovibrio guaymasensis
Extended Metabolism: Sulphur and nitrate serve as electron acceptors in the presence of H2 with the formation of H2S and ammonium, respectively. Sulphate, thiosulphate, sulphite, cystine, nitrite and oxygen are not used as electron acceptors

Name: Saccharolobus solfataricus
Extended Metabolism: Heterotrophic growth occurs on following complex substrates (peptone, tryptone, casamino acids) and variety of sugars (starch, sucrose, lactose, maltose, raffinose, D-glucose, D-mannose, D-arabinose and L-arabinose). Anaerobic growth on FeCl3 occurs in the presence of yeast extract. No chemolithotrophic growth occurs on elemental sulfur, pyrite and K2S4O6 . Growth by the oxidation of hydrogen weakly occurs.

Name: Desulfurolobus ambivalens
Extended Metabolism: capable of utilizing CO2 as sole carbon source and either SO + O2 (yielding sulfuric acid) or SO + H2 (yielding H2S) as energy sources.

Name: Sulfolobus acidocaldarius
Extended Metabolism:
strains isolated grow on elemental sulfur as a sole energy source. Even those strains which were enriched, isolated, and maintained for many generations on yeast extract grew on sulfur. Likewise, strains isolated on sulfur all grew on yeast extract. Growth did not diminish after many transfers on elemental sulfur, and growth on sulfur was stimulated by adding CO2 to the gas phase. Examination by fluorescence microscopy of acridine orange-stained cultures revealed numerous cells of Sulfolobus attached to sulfur crystals. Growth was always better on sulfur plus yeast extract than on sulfur
alone.

Name: Acidianus ambivalens
Extended Metabolism: It grows on sulphur, tetrathionate, iron (II) and sucrose under aerobic conditions, but it can also develop under anaerobic conditions using iron (III) or sulphur as electron acceptors and sulphur or hydrogen as electron donors autotrophically

Name: Methanocaldococcus indicus
Extended Metabolism: The novel isolate used H(2) and CO(2) as the only substrates for growth and produced methane. Selenium and yeast extract stimulated growth significantly. In the presence of CO(2) and H(2), the organism reduced elemental sulfur to hydrogen sulfide.

Name: Sulfolobus shibatae
Extended Metabolism: Growth inhibited by phosphate concentrations above about 10 mM. Yeast, D-arab, D-galactose, D-glucose, D-mannose, lactose, lactulose, maltose, sucrose, raffinose, starch, and tryptone utilized. Facultatively chemolithoautotrophic growth by sulphur oxidation. D
Note: Maybe the same as solfataricus B12

Name: Saccharolobus shibatae
Extended Metabolism: Growth occurs on following complex substrates (peptone, casamino acids). Chemolithotrophic growth occurs weakly on pyrite but not on elemental sulfur and K2S4O6 . Anaerobic growth on FeCl3 occurs in the presence of yeast extract. Growth by the oxidation of hydrogen weakly occurs.

Name: Thermotoga naphthophila
Extended Metabolism:
Requires yeast extract, peptone, glucose, galactose, fructose, mannitol, ribose, arabinose, sucrose, lactose, maltose or starch as the sole carbon and energy source. The end products from glucose fermentation are
acetate, lactate, H2 and CO2. While the cells reduce elemental sulfur to H2S, their growth rate and cellular yield decrease in the presence of elemental sulfur. While the species reduces thiosulfate weakly to H2S, thiosulfate shows no effect on the growth rate or cellular yield.

Name: Nanopusillus acidilobi
Extended Metabolism: symbiote

Name: Geoglobus acetivorans
Extended Metabolism: The isolate utilized acetate, formate, pyruvate, fumarate, malate, propionate, butyrate, succinate, glycerol, stearate, palmitate, peptone and yeast extract as electron donors for Fe(III) reduction. It was also capable of growth with H(2) as the sole electron donor, CO(2) as a carbon source and Fe(III) as an electron acceptor without the need for organic substances. Fe(III) [in the form of poorly crystalline Fe(III) oxide or Fe(III) citrate] was the only electron acceptor that supported growth

Name: Thermocrinis jamiesonii
Extended Metabolism: Obligately microaerophilic and chemolithotrophic, requiring thiosulfate as an electron donor. Autotrophic, but capable of chemolithoheterotrophy using peptone, Casamino acids or acetate. Vitamins are not required.

Name: Sulfolobus sp
Extended Metabolism: The strain appears to be able to fix CO2 via the HP/HB cycle. It is also capable of metabolizing glucose through a branched-ED pathway and the TCA cycle, as are other Sulfolobus strains

Name: Sulfolobus solfataricus
Extended Metabolism: has the ability to grow lithoautotrophically utilizing sulfur as an energy source or chemoheterotrophically on a variety of sugars and polysaccharides, including starch, as sole carbon and energy sources

Name: Palaeococcus helgesonii
Extended Metabolism: The isolate was obligately chemoheterotrophic, utilizing complex organic compounds including yeast or beef extract, peptone, tryptone, or casein for best growth. The presence of elemental sulfur enhanced growth.

Name: Thermococcus celericrescens
Extended Metabolism: Grows on yeast extract and tryptone. Sulfur is not necessary for growth, but enhances it

Name: Hydrogenobacter subterraneus
Extended Metabolism: h capable of utilizing a number of substrates such as yeast extract, peptone, tryptone, various carbohydrates, sugars, amino acids and organic acids. Elemental sulfur, thiosulfate, sulfide or cysteine-hydrochloride was required as an electron donor for growth. Hydrogen gas did not support growth

Name: Caldicellulosiruptor obsidiansis
Extended Metabolism: The organism also displayed fermentative growth on glucose, maltose, arabinose, fructose, starch, lactose, mannose, sucrose, galactose, xylose, arabinogalactan, Avicel, xylan, filter paper, processed cardboard, pectin, dilute acid-pretreated switchgrass, and Populus. OB47(T) was unable to grow on mannitol, fucose, lignin, Gelrite, acetate, glycerol, ribose, sorbitol, carboxymethylcellulose, and casein. Yeast extract stimulated growth, and thiosulfate, sulfate, nitrate, and sulfur were not reduced. Fermentation end products were mainly acetate, H2, and CO2, although lactate and ethanol were produced in 5-liter batch fermentations.

Name: Thermococcus zilligii
Extended Metabolism: Isolate AN1 has an absolute requirement for either Na+ or Li+ for growth. Sulfur [either as elemental sulfur (S0) or as cystine or oxidized glutathione with the sulfur being reduced to H2S] is also an absolute requirement. Sulfur could not be replaced by sulfate, sulfite or thiosulfite when the cultures were continuously gassed with N2.  The organism is strictly anaerobic, obligately heterotrophic growing on peptone (0.8%), casein or yeast extract. The following amino acids stimulate growth when the peptone concentration is 0.1%: glutamic acid, aspartic acid, tryptophan, alanine, leucine, valine, isoleucine, threonine and arginine. No growth is observed on carbohydrates, amino acids or organic acids when peptone is absent from the media.

Name: Archaeoglobus veneficus
Extended Metabolism:
sulfite-reduction, Molecular hydrogen served as electron donor during chemolithoautotrophic growth and H2S was
formed from sulfite or thiosulfate. Alternatively, organic acids, glucose, or ethanol were used as electron
donors

Name: Thermocrinis minervae
Extended Metabolism: The isolate grows chemolithotrophically with S(0), S(2)O(2)(3)(-) or H(2) as the electron donor and with O(2) (up to 16 %, v/v) as the sole electron acceptor. The isolate can grow on mannose, glucose, maltose, succinate, peptone, Casamino acids, starch, citrate and yeast extract in the presence of oxygen (4 %) and S(0)

Name: Desulfurobacterium pacificum
Extended Metabolism: Sulphur, thiosulphate and nitrate serve as electron acceptors in the presence of H2 with the formation of H2S and ammonium, respectively. Sulphate, sulphite, cystine, nitrite and oxygen are not used as electron acceptors.

Name: Hydrogenivirga okinawensis
Extended Metabolism: growth occurs with elemental sulfur and thiosulfate as electron donors and oxygen and nitrate as electron acceptors. Nitrate is reduced to nitrogen and sulfur is oxidized to sulfate and thiosulfate

Name: Sulfolobus acidocaldarius
Extended Metabolism:
strains isolated grow on elemental sulfur as a sole energy source. Even those strains which were enriched, isolated, and maintained for many generations on yeast extract grew on sulfur. Likewise, strains isolated on sulfur all grew on yeast extract. Growth did not diminish after many transfers on elemental sulfur, and growth on sulfur was stimulated by adding CO2 to the gas phase. Examination by fluorescence microscopy of acridine orange-stained cultures revealed numerous cells of Sulfolobus attached to sulfur crystals. Growth was always better on sulfur plus yeast extract than on sulfur
alone.

Name: Thermotoga caldifontis
Extended Metabolism: Growth is inhibited by elemental sulfur. In the presence of yeast extract, grows on D-glucose, maltose, trehalose, cellobiose, D-arabinose, D-xylose, D-ribose, pyruvate and starch. Uses thiosulfate but not elemental sulfur, sulfate, sulfite or nitrate as electron acceptors. In the absence of electron acceptors, syntrophic growth is observed with hydrogen scavengers such as M. thermautotrophicus.

Name: Thermus thermophilus
Extended Metabolism: Acid but no gas was produced fairly quickly from glucose and galactose and slowly from maltose and lactose. No acid was produced from sucrose or mannitol. The cells reduced litmus slowly at 75 C and slowly liquefied gelatin. They did not form indole from polypeptone or reduce nitrate.

Name: Thermoanaerobacter brockii
Extended Metabolism: Utilizes a variety of saccharides as energy sources, including starch, maltose, glucose, lactose, sucrose, and cellobiose. Growth is inhibited by air, penicillin, cycloserine, streptomycin, tetracycline, and chloramphenicol. The fermentation end products are ethanol, lactic acid, acetic acid, hydrogen, and carbon dioxide. Reduces thiosulfate to hydrogen sulfide.

Name: Fervidicoccus fontis
Extended Metabolism: The isolates were strictly anaerobic organotrophs and grew on a narrow spectrum of energy-rich substrates, such as beef extract, gelatin, peptone, pyruvate, sucrose and yeast extract, with yields above 107 cells/ml. Sulfate, sulfite, thiosulfate and nitrate added as potential electron acceptors did not stimulate growth when tested with peptone

Name: Acidianus manzaensis
Extended Metabolism: The acidophile was able to grow heterotrophically on several organic substrates, including various monosaccharides, alcohols and amino acids, though the growth on single substrate required yeast extract as growth factor. Growth occurred under aerobic conditions or via anaerobic respiration using elemental sulfur as terminal electron acceptor

Name: Sulfolobus solfataricus
Extended Metabolism: Utilized simple and complex carbohydrates as carbon sources as well as most amino acids except asparagine.  Sulfolobus strains can use single amino acids much more readily as the sole nitrogen source than as the sole carbon source.

Name: Archaeoglobus fulgidus
Extended Metabolism: sulfate reduction, autotrophically with sulfate or thiosulfate as electron acceptors

Name: Metallosphaera sedula
Extended Metabolism: It is capable of heterotrophic growth using complex organic molecules (with the exception of sugars), autotrophic growth by the fixation of carbon dioxide in the presence of H2 through an proposed modified 3-hydroxypropionate cycle, and its highest rates of growth are seen when grown mixotropically on casamino acids and metal sulfides

Name: Pseudothermotoga thermarum
Extended Metabolism: Yeast extract is required for growth. Addition of starch, glucose and maltose stimulate growth. Elemental sulfur is not reduced and prevents growth. Inhibition of growth by hydrogen.

Name: Methanotorris formicicus
Extended Metabolism: using hydrogen and carbon dioxide as sole energy and carbon sources. Formate was utilized as an alternative energy source

Name: Acidianus sulfidivorans
Extended Metabolism: It grows on sulphur, tetrathionate, iron (II) and sucrose under aerobic conditions, but it can also develop under anaerobic conditions using iron (III) or sulphur as electron acceptors and sulphur or hydrogen as electron donors autotrophically

Name: Thermus brockianus
Extended Metabolism: ability to use xylan as sole carbon source and degrade xylan-rich substrates

Name: Thermococcus indicus
Extended Metabolism: Growth of strain IOH1T was enhanced by starch, pyruvate, D(+)-maltose and maltodextrin as a carbon sources, and elemental sulfur as an electron acceptor.

Name: Caldicellulosiruptor kristjanssonii
Extended Metabolism: Grows on Avicel, cellobiose, dextrin, D-fructose, D-galactose, D-glucose, lactose, maltose, mannose, pectin, salicin, soluble starch, sucrose, trehalose, xylan and xylose. Does not utilize Dribose, L-arabinose, aesculin, glycerol, inulin, lactic acid, mannitol, pyruvate, raffinose, L-rhamnose, Dribose, sorbitol, casein peptone or yeast extract. The major fermentation end-products are acetic acid, H2 and CO2, with smaller amounts of lactic acid and ethanol and trace amounts of formic acid. No H2S from sulfate, thiosulfate or casein peptone.

Name: Caldicellulosiruptor kronotskyensis
Extended Metabolism: Utilizes cellulose, CM-cellulose, filter paper, starch, xylan, dextran, pectin, cellobiose, glucose, fructose, sucrose, xylose, galactose, maltose, lactose, arabinose, trehalose, mannitol, yeast extract and peptone. Does not grow with pyruvate, chitin, raffinose or ribose.

Name: Sulfolobus tokodaii
Extended Metabolism: Cells grow chemoheterotrophically on a modified Brock’s basal salts mixture supplied with tryptone, yeast extract, casamino acid, or amino acids under obligatory aerobic conditions. Best growth occurs on a modified Brock’s basal salts mixture supplied with yeast extract (1 g/l), casaminoic acid (1 g/l), and glucose (1 g/l). Supplements of elemental sulfur are not required for the chemoheterotrophic growth. Poor growth occurs under facultatively chemolithotrophic conditions in the presence of elemental sulfur when supplied with alanine (10 mg/l) or polypeptone (0.1 g/l)

Name: Dictyoglomus thermophilum
Extended Metabolism: The organism does not grow in media lacking fermentable carbohydrate. The carbohydrates used as energy sources include amygdalin, arabinose, cellobiose, fructose, fucose, galactose, glucose, lactose, maltose, mannose, melezitose, melibiose, pectin, raffinose, ribose, sucrose, trehalose, xylose, and insoluble starch of potato. Cellulose, merythritol, glycerol, L-inositol, mannitol, pyruvate, rhamnose, sorbitol, xylitol, and insoluble starch from corn and wheat are not fermented.

Name: Thermaerobacter marianensis
Extended Metabolism: Grows on yeast extract, peptone, starch, xylan, chitin, casein, Casamino acids, maltotriose, cellobiose, maltose, lactose, trehalose, saccharo se, glucose, galactose, xylose, mannitol, inositol, propionate, 2-aminobutyric acid, malate, pyruvate, tartrate, succinate, lactate, acetate, glycerol, valine, isoleucine, cysteine, proline, serine, threonine, asparagine, glutamine, aspartate, glutamate, lysine, arginine or histidine and weakly on cellulose, glycine, alanine, leucine, methionine or phenylalanine

Name: Phorcysia thermohydrogeniphila
Extended Metabolism: H2 as the energy source and CO2 as the carbon source. Nitrate and sulfur were used as electron acceptors, with concomitant formation of ammonium or hydrogen sulfide, respectively. The presence of lactate, formate, acetate or tryptone in the culture medium inhibited growth.

Name: Thermovibrio ammonificans
Extended Metabolism: Growth occurs under chemolithoautotrophic conditions in the presence of H2 and CO2, with nitrate or sulfur as electron acceptors and concomitant formation of ammonium or hydrogen sulfide, respectively. Thiosulfate, sulfite and oxygen are not used as electron acceptors. Acetate, formate, lactate and yeast extract (1 g/l) inhibit growth. No chemoorganoheterotrophic growth occurs on peptone, tryptone, yeast extract (0.1g/l), Casamino acids, glucose or sucrose.

Name: Thermovibrio ruber
Extended Metabolism: Chemolithoautotrophic growth in the presence of hydrogen and carbon dioxide with nitrate or elemental sulfur as the electron acceptor, with formation of ammonium or H2S, respectively. Sulfate, sulfite, thiosulfate, nitrite and oxygen are not used as electron acceptors. No chemo-organotrophic growth on meat extract, yeast extract, peptone, Casamino acids, gelatin, starch, formate, acetate or glucose.

Name: Thermoanaerobacter tengcongensis
Extended Metabolism: Heterotrophic growth requires yeast extract, which cannot be replaced by Tryptone or Casamino acids. Utilizes glucose, galactose, maltose, cellobiose, mannose, fructose, lactose, mannitol and starch, but not arabinose, sucrose, ribose, xylose, cellulose, alginate, xylan, acetate, pyruvate, butyrate, lactate, citrate, malate or glycerol. The major fermentation end product on glucose is acetate. Hydrogen and sulfite inhibit growth. Thiosulfate and sulfur stimulate growth.

Name: Archaeoglobus sulfaticallidus
Extended Metabolism: sulfate reduction

Name: Sulfurihydrogenibium rodmanii
Extended Metabolism: The following organic substrates were added at both 0.01 and 0.1 %, with and without O2 (and under a H2 or N2 gas phase) to determine potential carbon sources for heterotrophic or fermentative growth of all four strains: yeast extract (Difco), Bacto peptone (Difco), trypticase peptone, sucrose, glucose, starch, formate, Casamino acids, formaldehyde, formamide, citrate, propionate, acetate, 2- propanol, mannose, succinate, oxalate, lactate, methanol, fructose and maltose. Cultures were transferred at least twice to ensure that any growth observed was not due to substrate carry-over from the inoculum. None of the four strains was unable to utilize any organic carbon compounds, either as sole carbon sources or as energy sources.

Name: Metallosphaera prunae
Extended Metabolism: oxidation of S°, pyrite, sphalerite, chalcopyrite or molecular hydrogen. Alternatively yeast extract, peptone, and beef extract are used as energy sources during organotrophic growth

Name: Sulfolobus acidocaldarius
Extended Metabolism: grew by oxidation of So, pyrite, sphalerite, chalcopyrite or molecular hydrogen. Alternatively yeast extract, peprone, and beef extract arc used as energy sources during organotrophic growth.

Name: Caldicellulosiruptor owensensis
Extended Metabolism: Growth with arabinose, cellobiose, cellulose, dextrin, fructose, galactose, glucose, glycogen, inositol, lactose, mannitol, mannose, maltose, pectin, raffinose, rhamnose, ribose, starch, sucrose, tagatose, xylan, xylose and yeast extract. Does not grow on acetate, amygdalin, arbutin, erythritol, glycerol, lactate, melezitose, melibiose, methanol, pyruvate, sorbitol, trehalose, trypticase peptone or HJCO,. The fermentation products from glucose are acetate, lactate, ethanol, H, and CO,. The bacterium does not reduce nitrate, sulfate, sulfite and thiosulfate

Name: Persephonella marina
Extended Metabolism: Utilizes H2 , thiosulfate or S0 as an electron donor and O2, S0, or NO3- as an electron acceptor. N2 is formed from NO3- and H2S is formed from S0.

Name: Thermus filiformis
Extended Metabolism: Heterotrophic, using carbohydrates, organic acids, and amino acids as carbon sources. The substrates supporting growth include acetate, galactose, glucose, glutamate, mannitol, melibiose, proline, succinate, sucrose, and trehalose

Name: Caldisphaera lagunensis
Extended Metabolism: fermentative sulfur-reduction in an atmosphere of N2. Growth is stimulated by the presence of sulfur as an electron acceptor.

Name: Balnearium lithotrophicum
Extended Metabolism: growth occurs with molecular hydrogen as electron donor and with elemental sulfur as electron acceptor. Elemental sulfur is reduced to hydrogen sulfide during growth. Ammonium is required as nitrogen source. Vitamins, selenium and tungsten are not required for growth. Presence of nitrate and nitrite is inhibitory

Name: Desulfurobacterium atlanticum
Extended Metabolism: Thiosulphate and nitrate serve as electron acceptors in the presence of H2 with the formation of H2S and ammonium, respectively. Sulphur, sulphate, sulphite, cystine, nitrite and oxygen are not used as electron acceptors.

Name: Thermosipho japonicus
Extended Metabolism: Growth is inhibited by hydrogen. Growth occurs with yeast extract, peptone, tryptone, or casein as the sole carbon and energy source. Growth on these complex organic materials is enhanced in the presence of sulfur or thiosulfate. The species uses maltose and glucose with yeast extract, peptone, or tryptone; it also uses maltose, glucose, galactose, starch, saccharose, and ribose with casein

Name: Thermoanaerobacter pentosaceus
Extended Metabolism: Strain DTU01(T) could ferment arabinose, cellobiose, fructose, galactose, glucose, lactose, mannitol, mannose, melibiose, pectin, starch, sucrose, xylan, yeast extract and xylose, but not cellulose, Avicel, inositol, inulin, glycerol, rhamnose, acetate, lactate, ethanol, butanol or peptone. Ethanol was the major fermentation product and a maximum yield of 1.39 mol ethanol per mol xylose was achieved when sulfite was added to the cultivation medium. Thiosulfate, but not sulfate, nitrate or nitrite, could be used as electron acceptor.

Name: Caldanaerobacter subterraneus
Extended Metabolism: Acetate, L-alanine, lactate, H2 and CO2 are produced during glucose fermentation. Thiosulfate, but not sulfate, is used as an electron acceptor.

Name: Geobacillus sp
Extended Metabolism: Carbon source is carbohydrate or protein

Name: Desulfurobacterium thermolithotrophum
Extended Metabolism:
It did not use cystine, sulphate, nitrate or nitrite. Growth on sulphur, thiosulphate, polysulphides and sulphite was accompanied by exponential H,S production that paralleled
growth. Nitrate, tryptone and yeast extract were used as nitrogen sources. Yeast extract (0.2 YO) was found to be slightly inhibitory. The new organism was not able to grow in ASR medium in the presence of oxygen, even at low concentrations (0.2-1 %).

Name: Thermosipho melanesiensis
Extended Metabolism: Growth is supported by yeast extract or brain heart infusion alone or by malt extract, tryptone, and carbohydrates supplemented by yeast extract. For carbohydrates, decreasing yields of growth are obtained with sucrose and starch, glucose and maltose, lactose, cellobiose, and galactose. Meat extract, xylose, fructose, ethanol, mannitol, sorbitol, glycine, glycogen, formate, acetate and Casamino Acids do not support growth, even combined with yeast extract. Hydrogen inhibits growth, but this inhibition is overcome by the reduction of elemental sulfur. Under this condition, hydrogen sulfide is produced

Name: Methanothermobacter tenebrarum
Extended Metabolism: Acetate, formate, pyruvate, monomethylamine, dimethylamine, trimethylamine, methanol, ethanol, 1-propanol, 2-propanol, 1-butanol and 2-methylpropanol are not utilized for growth or methanogenesis. Non-autotrophic. Requires Casamino acids, tryptone, yeast extract or vitamin mixture for growth. Acetate stimulates growth

Name: Metallosphaera hakonensis
Extended Metabolism: The strain could extract metal ions from sulfidic ore. It was also able to oxidize reduced sulfur compounds. In addition, it was able to use heterogeneous organic materials for organotrophic growth.

Name: Thermus antranikianii
Extended Metabolism: Starch, casein, hide-powder azure and Tween 80 are hydrolyzed. Degradation of arbutin and aesculin is positive. Strains HN3-7T and HN2-7 do not hydrolyze elastin. Strains HN3-7T and HN2-7 utilize d- glucose, d-fructose, d-mannose, d-galactose, d-cellobiose, maltose, pyruvate, malate, L-glutamate, L-asparagine, L-glutamine, L-serine and L-proline. Strains HN3-7T and HN2-7 do not utilize D-xylose, D-melibiose, D-trehalose, D-raffinose, sucrose, D- mannitol, D-sorbitol, ribitol, xylitol, erythritol, myoinositol, L-sorbose, L-arabinose, L-rhamnose or L-fucose.

Name: Thermus composti
Extended Metabolism: Utilizes acetate, Casamino acids, Dfructose, D-glucose, trehalose, maltose and pyruvate. Does not utilize acetamide, citrate, D-galactose, raffinose, Dsorbitol, D-xylose, erythritol, formate, glycerol, lactose, Larabinose, L-rhamnose, L-serine, L-sorbose, myo-inositol or propionate. Weak growth is exhibited on cellobiose, melibiose, L-arginine, L-asparagine, L-glutamate, L-glutamine, malate and succinate.

Name: Thermus parvatiensis
Extended Metabolism: Strain RLT assimilated d-glucose, l-arabinose, d-mannose, d-mannitol, N-acetyl-glucosamine, d-maltose, potassium gluconate, capric acid, adipic acid, malic acid, trisodium citrate and phenylacetic acid. However the strain RLT did not ferment glucose. Neither did strain RLT hydrolyze esculin nor urease. nitrate-reduction and indole production was found to be negative

Name: Vulcanithermus mediatlanticus
Extended Metabolism: grew chemoorganoheterotrophically with carbohydrates, proteinaceous substrates, organic acids and alcohols using oxygen or nitrate as electron acceptors

Name: Caldicellulosiruptor saccharolyticus
Extended Metabolism: Acid is produced from arabinose, amorphous cellulose, avicell, cellobiose, fructose, galactose, glucose, glycogen, gum guar, gum locust bean, lactose, laminarin, lichenin, mannose, maltose, pullulan, pectin, rhamnose, Sigmacell 20, Sigmacell 50, Sigmacell 100, starch, sucrose, xylan, and xylose, but not from amygdalin, erythritol, glycerol, inositol, inulin, mannitol, melibiose, melezitose, raffinose, ribose, sorbitol, sorbose. Culture supernatants hydrolyzed carboxymethylcellulose, gum guar, gum locust bean, laminarin, lichenin, pullulan, starch, and xylan, but not arabinogalactan, chitin, glycogen, gum karaya, inulin, mannan

Name: Thermodesulfatator indicus
Extended Metabolism: Strictly chemolithoautotrophic using sulfate as electron acceptor and H2 as electron donor. No fermentative metabolism. With H2/CO2 and sulfate, growth is stimulated by methanol, monomethylamine, glutamate, peptone, fumarate, tryptone, isobutyrate, 3-CH3 butyrate, ethanol, propanol and low amounts of acetate. Unable to use sulfur, cystine, thiosulfate, sulfite, fumarate and nitrate as electron acceptor. Ammonium is the preferred nitrogen source

Name: Thermodesulfobacterium commune
Extended Metabolism: Fumarate and nitrate not reduced. Pyruvate is fermented to H2, C02 and acetate as end products. Growth with hydrogen as sole electron donor for energy metabolism. O

Name: Fervidobacterium pennivorans
Extended Metabolism: able to use starch, glycogen, pullulan, glucose, fructose, maltose, and xylose as growth substrates. Starch was the preferred carbon source. The new isolate was not able to utilize lactose, amylose, arabinose, casein, collagen, succinate, or Tween 80. The presence of 0.05% yeast extract was required for growth. Hydrogen gas had an inhibitory effect which could be eliminated by the addition of elemental sulfur or thiosulfate to the medium. The new isolate was a fermentative and strictly anaerobic microorganism. As fermentation products ethanol and acetate were found after 48 h of incubation at 708C; acetate was the major fermentation product.

Name: Clostridium fervidus
Extended Metabolism: Growth occurred on Trypticase peptone (BBL Microbiology Systems) or yeast extract. However, with the exception of serine, which could be catabolized as the sole carbon source, either peptone or yeast extract was essential for the fermentation of carbohydrates including glucose, maltose, mannose, xylan, starch, and pyruvate. Acetate was always the major fermentation end product. CO2, H2, and minor quantitites of valerate, butyrate, ethanol, and lactate were also produced.

Name: Thermus rehai
Extended Metabolism: The species has oxidase and catalase activity. Nitrate is reduced to nitrite. The new species utilizes glucose, acetate and galactose, but does not utilize sucrose and salicin, and does not hydrolyze starch and gelatin.

Name: Fervidobacterium nodosum
Extended Metabolism: wide range of carbohydrates including glucose, sucrose, starch and lactose could be utilized by the organism. Lactate, acetate, hydrogen, and carbon dioxide were the major end products of glucose fermentation with lesser amounts of ethanol being formed

Name: Fervidobacterium gondwanense
Extended Metabolism: Utilizes glucose, mannose, maltose, starch, amylopectin, cellobiose, carboxymethyl cellulose, lactose, dextrin, fructose, xylose, galactose, and pyruvate but not cellulose, Casamino Acids, gelatin, sorbose, ribose, raffinose, arabinose, dextran, xylan, or chitin. Produces acetate, ethanol, lactate, CO,, and H, during glucose fermentation. Reduces sulfur but not thiosulfate, sulfite, or sulfate.

Name: Thermoanaerobacter acetoethylicus
Extended Metabolism: Utilizes a variety of saccharides as energy sources including glucose, mannose, cellobiose, lactose, maltose, sucrose, and starch. Obligate anaerobe. Growth inhibited by air, NaC1 (2~), tetracycline, streptomycin, penicillin G, vankomycin, and neomycin. Major fermentation end products in glucose-complex medium include ethanol, acetate, isobutyrate, butyrate, hydrogen and carbon dioxide, but not lactate. Thiosulfate, but not sulfate, reduced to sulfide. Embden-Meyerhof glycolytic pathway.

Name: Hydrogenothermus marinus
Extended Metabolism: Grows chemolithoautotrophically under an atmosphere of H2 and CO2 (80: 20) with low concentrations of O2 (0±5–8%, optimum at 1–2%). No growth on meat peptone, tryptone, meat extract, yeast extract, lactose, galactose, glucose, ribose, fructose, sucrose, citric acid, maltose hydrate, starch, xylose, alanine, proline, histidine hydrochloride, glycine, methanol, ethanol, acetic acid, pyruvate, disodium fumarate, malate or ammonium formate as a source of energy or cellular carbon. Catalase- and cytochrome-oxidase-positive. No growth on peptone, yeast extract, tryptone, starch, glucose or maltose as sole electron donor. Sulfur and thiosulfate are not utilized as electron donors or sources of energy. Elemental sulfur is necessary for growth. Nitrate and sulfate cannot serve as electron acceptors

Name: Thermosipho atlanticus
Extended Metabolism: Weak growth was observed in the presence of yeast extract and peptone (YPS). Growth yield of strain DV1140T was enhanced either by replacing yeast extract or peptone with 2 g BHI l21 or by the addition of gelatin, starch, galactose, arabinose, glucose, trehalose or cellobiose to YPS. able to ferment BHI and also starch, galactose, arabinose, glucose, trehalose, cellobiose and gelatin in the presence of peptone and yeast extract. Elemental sulfur does not enhance growth.

Name: Kosmotoga olearia
Extended Metabolism: Maltose, ribose, sucrose, starch, Casamino acids, tryptone and pyruvate can serve as growth substrates. Fructose, galactose, mannose, raffinose, xylan, casein and peptone allow relatively weaker growth. Requires yeast extract for growth. Acetate, lactate and propionate inhibit growth slightly, while malate and butanol prevent growth. Under anaerobic conditions, maltose is fermented primarily into hydrogen, carbon dioxide and acetic acid. Traces of ethanol and propionic acid are detected, but not butyric acid or alanine. Arabinose, CM-cellulose, cellobiose, glucose, lactose, xylose, methanol, propanol, chitin, myo-inositol, putrescine and glycerol do not serve as carbon sources. Thiosulfate enhances growth, while elemental sulfur, nitrate and cystine do not. Sulfate also enhances growth, but sulfide is not produced. Sulfite inhibits growth slightly and nitrite prevents growth.

Name: Thermus igniterrae
Extended Metabolism: Elastin, starch, fibrin, casein, gelatin and hide-powder azure are hydrolyzed. Arbutin and aesculin are degraded. Strains RF-4T and HN1-8 utilize D-glucose, D-fructose, D-mannose, maltose, ribitol, pyruvate, L-glutamate, L-glutamine and L- proline. Strains RF-4T and HN1-8 do not utilize D-galactose, D-melibiose, D-cellobiose, D-raffinose, D- xylose, D-ribose, lactose, D-mannitol, D-sorbitol, xylitol, erythritol, glycerol, malate, citrate, myo-inositol, L-sorbose, L-fucose, L-arabinose, L-rhamnose, L-serine or L-arginine.

Name: Caldicellulosiruptor hydrothermalis
Extended Metabolism: Utilizes cellulose, CM-cellulose, filter paper, starch, xylan, dextran, pectin, cellobiose, glucose, fructose, sucrose, xylose, maltose, galactose, lactose, arabinose, mannitol and yeast extract. Does not grow with pyruvate, chitin, raffinose, trehalose, ribose or peptone

Name: Fervidobacterium islandicum
Extended Metabolism:
Yeast extract is required for growth. Addition of pyruvate, ribose, glucose, maltose, raffinose, starch, and cellulose stimulates growth. On glucose, 
L(+)lactate, acetate, ethanol, H2, CO2 and traces of  isobutyric and isovaleric acid are formed. Growth strictly anaerobic. H2 inhibits growth. Reduction of S °.

Name: Fervidobacterium riparium
Extended Metabolism: ferments peptone, yeast extract, pyruvate, sucrose, glucose, cellobiose, starch, xylan, microcrystalline cellulose (Avicel), CMC, amorphous cellulose, filter paper and birch sawdust. Glycerol, arabinose, lactose, pectin, dextran and chitin do not support growth. The main products of glucose fermentation are H2 and acetate. Elemental sulfur stimulates growth and is reduced by hydrogen, released during the course of fermentation. Sulfate, thiosulfate and nitrate do not influence growth, but sulfite inhibits it.

Name: Chloroflexus aurantiacus
Extended Metabolism: Chloroflexus is not an obligate phototroph, obligate anaerobe, or obligate autotroph. It grows well under fully aerobic conditions as a chemoheterotroph in the light or dark. Chloroflexus is primarily a photoheterotroph, although it may be capable of photoautotrophic growth. The presence of both photoheterotrophic and aerobic chemoheterotrophic metabolisms in Chloro/lexus resembles the physiological adaptability of the purple non-sulfur bacteria (Rhodospirillaceae).

Name: Thermus aquaticus
Extended Metabolism: No growth factor requirements (one strain tested). Nitrogen sources, amino acids and NH4+. Carbon sources, sugars, and organic acids. Grows best in complex media such as 0.1 to 0.3% tryptone plus yeast extract.

Name: Thermus islandicus
Extended Metabolism:
Weak growth is exhibited on cellobiose, lactose and inositol. Does not utilize arabinose, fructose, galactose, glucose, mannose, melibiose, raffinose, rhamnose, ribose,
sucrose, trehalose, xylose, ribitol, mannitol, sorbitol, citrate, malate, L-arginine, L-glutamine, L-serine or Casamino acids.

Name: Hydrogenobacter thermophilus
Extended Metabolism: Respiratory metabolism, using molecular oxygen as the electron acceptor. Chemolithotrophic, using molecular hydrogen as the electron donor and carbon dioxide as the carbon source. Chemoorganotrophic growth has not been found. Ammonium and nitrate salts are utilized as nitrogen sources. Growth factors are not required.

Name: Carboxydothermus hydrogenoformans
Extended Metabolism: Utilizes CO as the sole energy and carbon source with equimolar formation of H2 and CO2 according to the equation CO + H2 0 ---;. CO2 + H2• Other products are not formed. CO and H2 do not inhibit growth. Does not utilize any other inorganic and organic substrates. Does not reduce sulfate or sulfur

Name: Thermoanaerobacter italicus
Extended Metabolism: Xylan, starch, and glycogen are also utilized as carbon sources and thermoactive xylanolytic (highest activity at 70 degrees - 75 degrees C), amylolytic as well as pullulolytic enzymes (highest activity at 80 degrees - 85 degrees C) are formed

Name: Thermoanaerobacter siderophilus
Extended Metabolism: The substrates utilized in the presence, as well in the absence, of Fe(II1) as an electron acceptor include peptone, yeast extract, beef extract, starch, glycerol, pyruvate, glucose, sucrose, fructose, maltose, xylose, cellobiose and sorbitol. Utilizes molecular hydrogen in the presence of Fe(II1). No growth occurs with formate, acetate, lactate, methanol, ethanol, propan- 1-ol, propan-2-ol, butan- 1-ol, propionate, n-butyrate, succinate, malate, maleate, glycine, alanine, arginine, L-arabinose, olive oil, xylan or cellulose, either with or without Fe(II1) as an electron acceptor. The fermentation products from glucose are ethanol, lactate, H, and CO,. Reduces amorphous iron(II1) oxide, AQDS, sulfite, thiosulfate, elemental sulfur and MnO,. The products of amorphous iron(II1) oxide reduction are magnetite and siderite. Sulfite, thiosulfate and elemental sulfur are reduced to hydrogen sulfide. Does not reduce nitrate or sulfate and is incapable of growth with 02.

Name: Thermosulfidibacter takaii
Extended Metabolism: Utilization of organic carbon sources was tested in the absence of NaHCO3 in MMJS medium, using H2 as the headspace gas. The following substrates were added at 0.05 % (w/v): yeast extract (Difco), peptone, tryptone peptone (Difco), Casamino acids (Difco), glucose, maltose, fructose, sucrose, lactose, galactose, cellobiose, mannose, rhamnose, xylose, mannitol, glycerol, ethanol, methanol, fumarate, tartrate, acetate, formate, citrate, pyruvate, malate, propionate, succinate, mannitol, glutamate, glycine and alanine. Strain ABI70S6T could not utilize any of the organic compounds tested in this study as a sole carbon source. The results suggest that this strain is a chemolithoautotroph.

Name: Sulfurihydrogenibium yellowstonense
Extended Metabolism: s able to utilize a variety of organic compounds as sole carbon source (yeast extract, Bacto peptone, trypticase peptone, sucrose, glucose, starch, formate, Casamino acids, citrate, propionate, acetate; all at 0?1 %, w/v). No growth occurred in mjTSO medium lacking thiosulfate and elemental sulfur under a gas phase of 93 % CO2 and 7 % O2 (100 ) and in the presence of an organic carbon substrate, indicating that the isolate is unable to utilize organic substrates as energy sources.

Name: Kosmotoga pacifica
Extended Metabolism: The following substrates support growth in the presence of 0.02 % yeast extract: yeast extract, peptone, brain–heart infusion, tryptone, glycerol, maltose, xylose, glucose, fructose, cellobiose, trehalose, lactate, propionate and glutamate. The isolate does not use the following substrates as carbon and energy sources, even in the presence of small amounts of yeast extract: casamino acids, ethanol, malate, pyruvate, sucrose, galactose, ribose, starch and reduces Lcystine and elemental sulphur. Respiratory quinones were not detected.

Name: Thermoanaerobacter thermohydrosulfuricus
Extended Metabolism:
H, and CO, are produced in media containing liver infusion. H,S is produced from tryptophan, peptone, and yeast extract. Sulfite and thiosulfate
are reduced to H,S; sulfate is not reduced. Acetyl methyl carbinol is not produced. Fructose, galactose, glucose, mannose, xylose, cellobiose, maltose, sucrose, trehalose, pectin, esculin, and salicin are fermented. Fermentation of dextrin, potato starch, mannitol, dulcitol and sorbitol and coagulation of litmus milk are variable. Inositol, erythritol, glycerol, lactate, tartrate, and cellulose are not fermented; nitrite but not nitrate is reduced. Coagulated albumin is not hydrolyzed; indole is not produced. The products of metabolism in PYG broth are acetate, lactic acids, ethanol, CO,, and H,; formic, butyric, isovaleric, and isocaproic acids, propanol, and isopropanol may be detected.
